title: Rugby World Cup 2019: South Africa team guide
text:
Coach Rassie Erasmus

World rank 4

Previous best Winners

The Springboks have never gone into the World Cup in more harmony than in 2019, which is an alien concept to a team that generally flourishes in chaos.

But this year they have landed in Japan as the form team on the planet after winning the truncated Rugby Championship and being undefeated so far this calendar year.

They certainly don’t start the tournament as favourites, but for all future opponents the Boks are in alarmingly good shape.

Their coach, Rassie Erasmus, has developed a classy squad in limited time after taking over from the calamitous Allister Coetzee in early 2018.

Erasmus has built depth in every position, developed a strong gameplan and a core group of leaders that makes this a squad capable of winning the whole shindig, something that seemed impossible less than two years ago.

Coetzee’s short tenure was pockmarked with unwanted milestones for the Boks such as a record 57-0 loss to the All Blacks in 2017 and a first ever loss to Italy in late 2016.

Inside 18 months Erasmus has taken largely the same group of players and turned them into the southern hemisphere’s leading team going into the World Cup. It seems like he has performed magic, but he has really only applied logic.

The word used most to describe Erasmus by those that work, or have worked, with him is “meticulous”. When he was asked to coach the Boks in addition to his role as director of rugby at the SA Rugby Union, Erasmus already had a clear vision for the country’s flagship team.

With only 19 Tests before their opening game against the All Blacks in Yokohama on 21 September, Erasmus did not waste a minute.

He started by appointing a captain who would rally the nation, and the team, behind him. In one of those quirks of timing, Siya Kolisi had emerged as a strong leader of the Stormers and as a figure who could unite the country around the Springboks.

Erasmus recognised this, and his decision to appoint Kolisi as the first black Test captain has been a brilliant one. Kolisi in turn, has more than met the challenge of one of the toughest jobs in sport to become an iconic leader.

Erasmus also needed to build depth. He said the Boks would have to take some losses along the way to do it. They did, but there was always a bigger plan.

Erasmus clarified tactics, prioritised set piece and defence and helped develop Faf de Klerk into a world-class scrum-half, which was a vital piece of the missing puzzle.

The aggressive defensive system the Boks employ, by shutting space from the outside in, is risky and took time to mature. But the recent signs are that the team is now comfortable with it. The scrum has been a huge area of strength and the Bok lineout is also imperious and from these platforms they build the foundation for wins.

Under the circumstances despite the tight timeframe, Erasmus has got the Boks to Japan in magnificent form and full of confidence. No one could ask for more.

• Craig Ray is a Cape Town-based sports writer and author
description: The Springboks go into the tournament as the form team on the planet thanks to Rassie Erasmus’s superb stewardship
